across.text: Short couple returning pawnbroker’s gem
across.explanation: CARBUNCLE(i.e. “gem”). Solution is BRACE (i.e. “couple”) with the last letter removed (indicated by “short”) and the remainder reversed (indicated by “returning”), followed by UNCLE (a slang word for a “pawnbroker”), like so: CARB-UNCLE.

across.text: Including a feature with note passed across counter
across.explanation: ADDING MACHINE(i.e. “counter”). Solution is ADDING (i.e. “including”) followed ME (i.e. “note” in the doh-ray-me notation) once it has been wrapped around or “passed across” A and CHIN (i.e. “[facial] feature”), like so: ADDING-M(A-CHIN)E.

across.text: Rowed and yelled, losing head
across.explanation: OARED(i.e. “rowed”). Solution is ROARED (i.e. “yelled”) with the first letter removed (indicated by “losing head”).

across.text: Imagined names to cover old area one’s set in
across.explanation: NONEXISTENT(i.e. “imagined”). Solution is N and N (both recognised abbreviations of “name”) wrapped around or “covering” O (a recognised abbreviation of “old”) and followed by EXTENT (i.e. “area”) once I’S (i.e. “[Roman numeral] one’s”) been “set in”, like so: N(O)N-EX(I’S)TENT.

across.text: Assign many, about 50
across.explanation: ALLOT(i.e. “assign”). Solution is A LOT (i.e. “many”) wrapped “about” L (i.e. “[Roman numeral] fifty), like so: A-(L)-LOT.

across.text: Love being in a strip club, dancing, hot and humid?
across.explanation: SUBTROPICAL(i.e. “hot and humid”). Solution is O (i.e. “love”, being a zero score in tennis) placed “in” an anagram (indicated by “dancing”) of STRIP CLUB, like so: SUBTR(O)PICAL.

across.text: One female detected hole in a jug, a Paris icon
across.explanation: EIFFEL TOWER(i.e. “a Paris icon”). Solution is I (i.e. “[Roman numeral] one”), F (a recognised abbreviation of “female”), FELT (i.e. “detected”) and O (i.e. “hole” – as in the letter’s resemblance to one) all placed “in” EWER (i.e. “jug”), like so: E(I-F-FELT-O)WER.

across.text: Alluring type in charge of cutting record
across.explanation: ENTICER(i.e. “alluring type”). Solution is IC (a recognised abbreviation of “in charge”) placed in or “cutting” ENTER (i.e. “[to] record”), like so: ENT(IC)ER.

across.text: Mole spotted everyone grabbing European
across.explanation: SEAWALL(i.e. “mole” – one of the various meanings of the word is “a massive breakwater”). Solution is SAW (i.e. “spotted”) and ALL (i.e. “everyone”) wrapped around or “grabbing European”), like so: S(E)AW-ALL.

across.text: A river by old US city yields gold ring
across.explanation: AUREOLA(i.e. a halo, corona or “gold ring”). Solution is A followed by URE (i.e. “river”), then O (a recognised abbreviation of “old”) and LA (i.e. “US city”, specifically Los Angeles).

across.text: Implying convoluted legal nicety, maybe controversially engineered?
across.explanation: GENETICALLY MODIFIED(i.e. “maybe controversially engineered”). Solution cryptically satisfies “implying convoluted legal nicety”, in that “legal nicety” is an anagram or MODIFIED form of GENETICALLY.

across.text: One who admires fine article
across.explanation: FAN(i.e. “one who admires”). Solution is F (a recognised abbreviation of “fine” used in grading pencils) followed by AN (i.e. “article”, being a word like a, an or the).

across.text: What some casual readers do? Take drugs
across.explanation: DOG-EAR. Solution satisfies “what some casual readers do” – referring to the abhorrent practice of folding the corner of a page to mark one’s place in a book – and, when written as DO GEAR, also satisfies “take drugs”.

across.text: Yell “Clear off!”, seizing tablet
across.explanation: SCREAM(i.e. “yell”). Solution is SCRAM (i.e. “clear off!”) wrapped around E (street name of the drug ecstasy, often taken in “tablet” form), like so: SCR(E)AM.

across.text: Actor’s exit stumped old men packing circle
across.explanation: STAGE DOOR(i.e. “actor’s exit”). Solution is ST (a recognised abbreviation of “stumped” used in cricket) followed by AGED (i.e. “old”) and OR (i.e. “men”, specifically the Other Ranks of the British Army) wrapped around or “packing” O (i.e. “circle”), like so: ST-AGED-(O)-OR.

across.text: Crossing lake, supports pale Oz bird
across.explanation: BLACK SWAN(i.e. “Oz bird”). Solution is BACKS (i.e. “supports”) wrapped around or “crossed” by L (a recognised abbreviation of “lake”) and followed by WAN (i.e. “pale”), like so: B(L)ACKS-WAN.

across.text: Muscle oil company’s used to guard diamonds
across.explanation: BICEPS(i.e. “muscle”). Solution is BP’S (i.e. “oil company’s”, specifically British Petroleum, made possessive) wrapped around or “guarding” ICE (i.e. “diamonds”), like so: B(ICE)P’S.

across.text: With bottle of mineral knocked back, resultant sound going about?
across.explanation: HEROIC(i.e. “with bottle”). Solution is ORE (i.e. “mineral”) reversed (indicated by “knocked back”) and placed in, or having “about”, HIC (i.e. “resultant sound”, i.e. a hiccup, the implication being one has knocked something back a little too quickly), like so: H(ERO)IC.

across.text: Community gathering endless drink
across.explanation: BEE(i.e. “community gathering”, like a sewing bee). Solution is BEER (i.e. “drink”) with its last letter removed (indicated by “endless”).

across.text: Everything under discussion I’ve used with our forensics nuts
across.explanation: UNIVERSE OF DISCOURSE(i.e. “everything under discussion”). “Nuts” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of I’VE USED and OUR FORENSICS.

across.text: Popular teams showing guts
across.explanation: INSIDES(i.e. “guts”). Solution is IN (i.e. “popular”) followed by SIDES (i.e. “teams”).

across.text: Playwright’s very large book, one gripping queen
across.explanation: JohnOSBORNE(i.e. “playwright”). Solution is OS (i.e. “very large”, specifically a recognised abbreviation of “outsize”) followed by B (a recognised abbreviation of “book”) and ONE once it has been wrapped around or “gripping” R (a recognised abbreviation of Regina, Latin for “queen”), like so: OS-B-O(R)NE.

across.text: Weeds grow wild, eaten by rodent
across.explanation: RAGWORT(i.e. “weeds”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “wild”) of GROW placed on or “eaten by” RAT (i.e. “rodent”), like so: RA(GWOR)T.

across.text: Second service stops religious breaking with tradition
across.explanation: MODERNISTIC(i.e. “breaking with tradition”). Solution is MO (shortened form of “moment”, i.e. “second”) followed by RN (i.e. “[armed] service”, specifically the Royal Navy) once it has been placed in or “stopping” DEISTIC (i.e. “religious”), like so: MO-DE(RN)ISTIC.

across.text: Title associated with range in US, I’d say?
across.explanation: APPELLATION(i.e. “title”). “I’d say” indicates homophone. Solution is a homophone of the APPALACHIAN mountain “range in US”.

across.text: Hotel in Med resort designed for specific market
across.explanation: NICHE(i.e. “designed for specific market”). Solution is H (“Hotel” in the phonetic alphabet) placed “in” NICE (i.e. “Med resort”), like so: NIC(H)E.

across.text: Encouraging cool strong drink in gallons
across.explanation: INSPIRITING(i.e. “encouraging”). Solution is IN (i.e. “cool” or popular) followed by SPIRIT (i.e. “strong drink”), then IN and G (a recognised abbreviation of “gallons”).

across.text: Irish oddly acquit Arab
across.explanation: IRAQI(i.e. “Arab”). Solution is IR (a recognised abbreviation of “Irish”) followed by every other letter (indicated by “oddly”) ofACQUIT, like so: IR-AQI.

across.text: A girl into maths briefly disputed term in it
across.explanation: ANTILOGARITHM(i.e. “term in [maths]”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “disputed”) of A GIRL INTO and MATHS once its last letter has been removed (indicated by “briefly”).

across.text: County dismisses charter
across.explanation: YORKSHIRE(i.e. “county”). Solution is YORKS (i.e. “dismisses” a batsman in cricket with a yorker, a specific type of delivery) followed by HIRE (i.e. “[to] charter”).

down.text: Like relaxed Buddhist, thwarted touring large cell
down.explanation: CROSS-LEGGED(i.e. “like relaxed Buddhist”). Solution is CROSSED (i.e. “thwarted”) wrapped around or “touring” L (a recognised abbreviation of “large”) and EGG (i.e. “cell”), like so: CROSS(L-EGG)ED.

down.text: Two groups of soldiers chewed toastie
down.explanation: RAREBIT(i.e. “toastie”). Solution is RA and RE (i.e. “two groups of soldiers”, specifically the Royal Artillery and Royal Engineers of the British Army) followed by BIT (i.e. “chewed”).

down.text: Jack doesn’t start to shake milk container
down.explanation: UDDER(i.e. “milk container”). Solution is JUDDER (i.e. “shake”) with the J removed (indicated by “Jack doesn’t start” – J is a recognised abbreviation of “Jack” used in playing cards).

down.text: Plot against second main crime
down.explanation: CONSPIRACY(i.e. “plot”). Solution is CON (i.e. “against”, as in pros and cons) followed by S (a recognised abbreviation of “second”) and PIRACY (i.e. “main crime” – setters love referring to the sea as “main”).

down.text: Sultan’s guards regularly return such bananas
down.explanation: EUNUCHS(i.e. “Sultan’s guards”). Solution is every other letter (indicated by “regularly”) of RETURNfollowed by an anagram (indicated by “bananas”) of SUCH, like so: EUN-UCHS.

down.text: Will should have three examples of this
down.explanation: AUXILIARY VERB. “Three examples of this” are the auxiliary verbs “will”, “should” and “have”. These are verbs which add function or grammatical meaning to a clause, e.g. “shewilldo something”, “sheshoulddo something” or “theyhavedone something”.

down.text: Outlaw some French and English in gallery
down.explanation: DESPERADO(i.e. “outlaw”). Solution is DES (i.e. “some French”, i.e. the French for “some”) followed by E (a recognised abbreviation of “English”) once it has been placed “in” PRADO (i.e. Spain’s national art “gallery”), like so: DES-P(E)RADO.

down.text: End fuel supply that’s essential
down.explanation: NEEDFUL(i.e. “essential”). “Supply” indicates anagram, as in something being supple – sneaky, eh? Solution is an anagram of END FUEL.

down.text: Rigorous man abridged inspiring article about subject
down.explanation: MATHEMATICAL(i.e. “rigorous”). Solution is MALE (i.e. “man”) with the last letter removed (indicated by “abridged”) and the remainder wrapped around or “inspiring” A (i.e. “article”, as in a word like a, an or the) and THEMATIC (i.e. “subject”), like so: M(A-THEMATIC)AL.

down.text: Like some accountants about to be drafted outside
down.explanation: CHARTERED(i.e. “like some accountants”). Solution is RE (i.e. “about” – think email replies) with CHARTED (i.e. “drafted”) placed “outside” of it, like so: CHARTE(RE)D.

down.text: Relative’s trendy wife bagging French article
down.explanation: IN-LAW(i.e. “relative”). Solution is IN (i.e. “trendy”) and W (a recognised abbreviation of “wife”) wrapped around or “bagging” LA (i.e. “French article”, i.e. the French for “the”), like so: IN-(LA)-W.

down.text: Register English church composer without top performer
down.explanation: ENTERTAINER(i.e. “performer”). Solution is ENTER (i.e. “register”) followed by Sir John STAINER (i.e. “English church composer” – no, me neither. Chalk one to my Bradfords here) with the first letter removed (indicated by “without top”), like so: ENTER-TAINER.

down.text: Trim copper heading to seize book
down.explanation: CUT BACK(i.e. “trim”). Solution is CU (chemical symbol of “copper”) followed by TACK (i.e. “heading” or course) wrapped around or “seizing” B (a recognised abbreviation of “book”), like so: CU-T(B)ACK.

down.text: Sick of quartet entertaining officer
down.explanation: OFF COLOUR(i.e. “sick”). Solution is OF followed by FOUR (i.e. “quartet”) wrapped around or “entertaining” COL (i.e. “officer”, specifically a recognised abbreviation of a colonel), like so: OF-F(COL)OUR.

down.text: Restricted zones in Genoa or Siena, extremely mysterious
down.explanation: NO-GO AREAS(i.e. “restricted zones”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “mysterious”) of GENOA OR and SA (i.e. “Siena, extremely”, i.e. the first and last letters of “Siena”).

down.text: Permit fifty-one churches to keep name
down.explanation: LICENCE(i.e. “permit”). Solution is LI (i.e. “fifty-one” in Roman numerals) followed by CE and CE (i.e. “churches”, specifically the Church of England) wrapped around or “keeping” N (a recognised abbreviation of “name”), like so: LI-CE-(N)-CE.

down.text: On reflection, sauce is not ideal at first, being tasteless
down.explanation: INSIPID(i.e. “tasteless”). Solution is DIP (i.e. “sauce”) followed by IS, then N and I (i.e. “not ideal at first”, i.e. the first letters of “not” and “ideal”). The whole is then reversed (indicated by “on reflection”), like so: I-N-SI-PID.

down.text: Grim CIA morons spread spore maybe
down.explanation: MICRO-ORGANISM(i.e. “spore maybe”). “Spread” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of GRIM CIA MORONS.

down.text: Spanish article about golf catches on soon
down.explanation: ERELONG(i.e. “soon”). Solution is EL (for “Spanish article”, i.e. the Spanish for “the”), ON (i.e. “about”) and G (“golf” in the phonetic alphabet) all wrapped about or “catching” RE (i.e. “on” or about – think email replies), like so: E(RE)L-ON-G. I’ve twisted over this one for a while, and this seems the best solution I can get, but I’m not exactly cock-a-hoop about it. Using ON for “about” only to then use RE for “on” feels weirdly off, like a circular reference in a spreadsheet or something.[Reads that back.]Bloody hell, I’m such a nerd…

down.text: Hoping to drink German wine that’s sublime
down.explanation: AWE-INSPIRING(i.e. “sublime”). Solution is ASPIRING (i.e. “hoping”) wrapped around or “drinking” WEIN (i.e. “German [for] wine”), like so: A(WEIN)SPIRING.

down.text: I’m in Bilbao crazily nursing a passion for shelf-stacking?
down.explanation: BIBLIOMANIA(i.e. “passion for shelf-stacking”, as in having a thing for books). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “crazily”) of I’M IN BILBAO wrapped around or “nursing” A, like so: BIBLIOM(A)NIA.

down.text: Helm saves energy, anxious about four covering same length
down.explanation: COEXTENSIVE(i.e. “covering same length”). Solution is COX (i.e. “helm”) wrapped around or “saving” E (a recognised abbreviation of “energy”) and followed by TENSE (i.e. “anxious”) once this has been wrapped around or “covering” IV (i.e. “four” in Roman numerals), like so: CO(E)X-TENS(IV)E.

down.text: Star analyst runs over diary penned by Daisy
down.explanation: ASTROLOGER(i.e. “star analyst”). Solution is R (a recognised abbreviation of “runs” used in a number of ball games), O (a recognised abbreviation of an “over” in cricket) and LOG (i.e. “diary”) all placed in or “penned by” ASTER (i.e. “daisy” – ignore the misleading capitalisation), like so: AST(R-O-LOG)ER.

down.text: Waterproof submarine, second in Clyde
down.explanation: UNDERSEAL(i.e. “[to] waterproof”). Solution is UNDERSEA (i.e. “submarine”) followed by L (i.e. “second in Clyde”, i.e. the second letter of “Clyde”).

down.text: Small number possibly needing to edit screenplay perhaps
down.explanation: SUBSCRIPT(i.e. “small number possibly” – subscripts can be text too). When read as SUB SCRIPT, the solution also satisfies “edit screenplay perhaps”.

down.text: Less intelligent old boy beginning to transform addict
down.explanation: OBTUSER(i.e. “less intelligent”). Solution is OB (a recognised abbreviation of “old boy”, or alumnus) followed by T (i.e. “beginning to transform”, i.e. the first letter of “transform”) and USER (i.e. “[drug] addict”).

down.text: Bronte sister admits exercising with no effect
down.explanation: EMPTILY(i.e. “with no effect”). Solution is EMILY (i.e. “Bronte sister”) wrapped around or “admitting” PT (i.e. “exercising”, specifically a recognised abbreviation of Physical Training), like so: EM(PT)ILY.

down.text: Ring friend abroad about kit for art in Tokyo
down.explanation: ORIGAMI(i.e. “art in Tokyo”). Solution is O (i.e. “ring”) and AMI (i.e. “friend abroad”, i.e. the French for “friend”) wrapped “about” RIG (i.e. “kit”), like so: O-(RIG)-AMI.

down.text: Old coin originally accepted in tube
down.explanation: DUCAT(i.e. “old coin”). Solution is A (i.e. “originally accepted”, i.e. the first letter of “accepted”) placed “in” DUCT (i.e. “tube”), like so: DUC(A)T.

down.text: Section of program is simply wrong
down.explanation: AMISS(i.e. “wrong”). “Section of” indicates the solution has been hidden in the clue, like so: PROGR(AM IS S)IMPLY.
